Nothing is being contradicted.  You just have a grossly flawed understanding of the laws.   The first law states that an object in uniform motion will remain in that same exact state of uniform motion if no unbalanced forces are acting upon it.  The third law states that every force has an equal and opposite reaction force.   An object will NOT remain in its state of motion of an unbalanced force is acting on it.  You say it will; that's not what law of inertia says.  A book remains at rest on a table because there are no unbalanced forces acting on it.  There are two forces acting on the book.  You mention only one of these forces (the table pushing upward on the book).  There is an equal force to this in the downward direction : gravity.  These two forces both act on the book in opposite directions, and therefore cancel each other.  They are balanced.   Perhaps you are just confused - because the two forces I mentioned that were acting on the book are NOT a force pair.  Force pairs NEVER act on the same body.  There are two DIFFERENT force pairs at work here.  You have the force of gravity on the book from the Earth - the opposite being the force of gravity on the Earth from the book.  Then you have the actual contact force the book exerts on the Earth - the opposite of which is the table pushing up on the book.  When you identify all of these forces, you find two forces acting on the book that cancel each other.  All force pairs are identified and are consistent with Newton's third law, and the law of inertia is not violated.

The second law just describes how forces, mass and resulting acceleration all relate to each other.  It is summarized by the equation, F=ma.  It means that the force on an object (which is technically the sum of all forces acting on an object) is equal to the mass of the object times the acceleration.     It means if you apply a force to an object, it will accelerate at a rate which depends on its own mass.  If the force is twice as much, the acceleration will be twice as much.  If the mass is twice as much, the acceleration will be cut in half.

The entire record does not travel the same speed.  45 rpm is not a speed; it's just revolutions per minute.  To determine the speed, you have to multiply the rpm by the circumference.  A typical record is 12 inches in diameter, so the circumference would be 37.7 inches or so.  At 45 rpm, this is about 1,697 inches per minute - which is 2.4 ft/s.  The inner part of the record is not going as fast.  It's still 45 revolutions per minute, but each revolution is a shorter distance.  For example, if you just go 3 inches out from the center, that would be a diameter of 5 inches, or a circumference of 18.8 inches.  At 45 rpm, this is 846 inches per minute, or about 1.2 ft/s - half the speed.

@AJ-yo7rb  Yeah, that doesnt answer my question.  Newtons third law has always existed.  Literally every mechanical machine that has ever been invented has relied on it since the beginning of humanity despite it not being defined until Newton came along, and you're sitting here talking about sending up a balloon to prove it.

The reason it hurts to punch a ball, but doesn't hurt to throw a ball is because the acceleration during the punch is a LOT higher - albeit for a shorter amount of time.  The force on the ball is only being applied for a very short time.  Suppose that you can accelerate your hand up to 20 m/s, and for the sake of simplicity, you can do this whether you have a ball in your hand or not.  When you punch the ball, your hand is only in contact with that ball for a tiny fraction of a second, but the ball accelerates up to 20 m/s.  So, the ball goes from 0 m/s to 20 m/s in something like 0.05 seconds.  The acceleration here is v/t, or 20 / .05 = 400 m/s².  The mass of a typical football is about 0.4 kg, so the force exerted is F = ma, or 0.4 * 400 = 160 Newtons.     When you throw a ball, you are in contact with the ball for a lot longer.  Probably about half a second.  You still accelerate the ball up to 20 m/s, but you do so over 0.5 seconds, so the acceleration then is only 40 m/s² which means the force was only 16 Newtons.   This force also acts back on you, so it would make sense that the one with the force of 160 Newtons (10 times the force on the throw) would hurt while the throw does not.   In your ice example, assuming it is a frictionless surface, you would accelerate backwards as soon as you started applying a force to the other person and for as long as you are applying a force to the other person with equal mass - and that person would accelerate in the opposite direction at the same rate.  Once you are no longer making contact (no longer applying a force), you would still move, but you would not be accelerating anymore.  You would just continue with whatever velocity you had the moment you stopped applying a force.   A shower nozzle reacting to water coming out, a firearm recoil, and rockets are all examples of Newton's third law at work as well.  These things all work the exact same way as the ice skating example.  Forces always come in pairs - without exception.  There is also another concept very closely related to Newton's third law that applies in these examples as well and that is the conservation of momentum.  Within any arbitrary system, the combined momentum of all parts of that system will remain constant.   First off, momentum is simply mass times velocity (p =mv).  Take a rocket.  The momentum of all that mass that makes up that rocket, and all the fuel inside that rocket - forever and ever will remain constant (unless it interacts with something outside our defined system).  Our defined system is just the rocket and all its fuel.  Suppose this rocket is just sitting in space stationary.  It's velocity is zero, ergo the momentum is zero.  The combined momentum of all that mass will always remain at zero.  Let's suppose our rocket has a mass of 10,000 kg.  This rocket fires up the engine and ejects 2,500 kg of mass at 500 m/s.  While all that fuel is no longer in the rocket, it's still part of our system, and the momentum of just the fuel is now 2,500 * 500 = 1,250,000 kg m/s.  Remember, the momentum of the system is conserved, so the remaining 7,500 kg of mass in the rocket must necessarily have a momentum of -1,250,000 kg m/s to offset the momentum of the ejected fuel to maintain the total momentum of zero.  Ergo, the rocket must be propelled in the opposite direction at v = p/m = -1,250,000 / 7,500 = 166.7 m/s.  The same logic can be applied to water shooting out of a hose or a bullet shooting out of a gun.  You can look at all these things from either a Newton's third law perspective or a conservation of momentum perspective.  They are two sides of the same coin.

She's thinking like a mathematical physicist where everything leads to some math equations without really explaining the mechanism of what's happening.  In the case of the local loop, all we need to be concerned with (related to the motions described) are the reference (what's not moving) and how the things that are moving move relative to that datum...and, how/why. The velocity of the rotation of the Earth or the speed the Earth orbits the Sun or the rate the galaxy moves through the cosmos can be ignored.  There are compressions and rarefactions of the local environment. As the reindeer hooves push against the ground they compress the ground molecules toward the sleigh (and they relax ahead of the hooves).
